element.definition: Comments on the slot to describe any extended information. Such as custom constraints on the slot.

resource.name: Specimen
resource.publisher: Health Level Seven International (Orders and Observations)

element.definition: A sample to be used for analysis.
Id for specimen.
The identifier assigned by the lab when accessioning specimen(s). This is not necessarily the same as the specimen identifier, depending on local lab procedures.
The availability of the specimen.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: Codes providing the status/availability of a specimen.

element.short: Kind of material that forms the specimen
element.definition: The kind of material that forms the specimen.
element.comment: The type can change the way that a specimen is handled, and drives what kind of analyses can properly be performed on the specimen. It is frequently used in diagnostic work flow decision making systems.

binding.description: The type of the specimen.

element.short: Where the specimen came from. This may be from the patient(s) or from the environment or a device
element.definition: Where the specimen came from. This may be from the patient(s) or from the environment or a device.
element.requirements: Must know the subject context.

element.short: The time when specimen was received for processing
element.definition: Time when specimen was received for processing or testing.

element.short: Specimen from which this specimen originated
element.definition: Reference to the parent (source) specimen which is used when the specimen was either derived from or a component of another specimen.
element.comment: The parent specimen could be the source from which the current specimen is derived by some processing step (e.g. an aliquot or isolate or extracted nucleic acids from clinical samples) or one of many specimens that were combined to create a pooled sample.

element.definition: Details concerning a test or procedure request that required a specimen to be collected.
element.comment: The request may be explicit or implied such with a ProcedureRequest that requires a blood draw.

element.definition: Details concerning the specimen collection.
Person who collected the specimen.
Time when specimen was collected from subject - the physiologically relevant time.
The quantity of specimen collected; for instance the volume of a blood sample, or the physical measurement of an anatomic pathology sample.
A coded value specifying the technique that is used to perform the procedure.

binding.description: The  technique that is used to perform the procedure

element.definition: Anatomical location from which the specimen was collected (if subject is a patient). This is the target site.  This element is not used for environmental specimens.
element.comment: If the use case requires  BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately)  then use the standard extension [body-site-instance](extension-body-site-instance.html).

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.definition: Details concerning processing and processing steps for the specimen.
Textual description of procedure.

element.short: Indicates the treatment step  applied to the specimen
element.definition: A coded value specifying the procedure used to process the specimen.

binding.description: Type indicating the technique used to process the specimen

element.short: Material used in the processing step
element.definition: Material used in the processing step.

element.short: Date and time of specimen processing
element.definition: A record of the time or period when the specimen processing occurred.  For example the time of sample fixation or the period of time the sample was in formalin.
The container holding the specimen.  The recursive nature of containers; i.e. blood in tube in tray in rack is not addressed here.
Id for container. There may be multiple; a manufacturer's bar code, lab assigned identifier, etc. The container ID may differ from the specimen id in some circumstances.
Textual description of the container.

element.short: Kind of container directly associated with specimen
element.definition: The type of container associated with the specimen (e.g. slide, aliquot, etc.).

binding.description: Type of specimen container

element.definition: The capacity (volume or other measure) the container may contain.

mapping.map: one of: SAC 16, SAC17 and SAC 20, or SAC 21 and SAC 20

element.definition: The quantity of specimen in the container; may be volume, dimensions, or other appropriate measurements, depending on the specimen type.
Introduced substance to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.

binding.description: Substance added to specimen container

element.definition: To communicate any details or issues about the specimen or during the specimen collection. (for example: broken vial, sent with patient, frozen).

A definition of a FHIR structure. This resource is used to describe the underlying resources, data types defined in FHIR, and also for describing extensions and constraints on resources and data types.

constraint.requirements: Because these 3 fields seem to be have overlapping meaning with the ones in the root of StructureDefinition
constraint.human: In any snapshot or differential, no label, code or requirements on the an element without a "." in the path (e.g. the first element)
constraint.xpath: not(exists(f:snapshot/f:element[not(contains(f:path/@value, '.')) and (f:label or f:code or f:requirements)])) and not(exists(f:differential/f:element[not(contains(f:path/@value, '.')) and (f:label or f:code or f:requirements)]))

constraint.requirements: custom types only in logical models
constraint.human: Custom types can only be used in logical models
constraint.expression: kind = 'logical' or (differential.element.type.code.all(hasValue() implies matches('^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$')) and snapshot.element.type.code.all(hasValue() implies matches('^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$')))
constraint.xpath: f:kind/@value = 'logical' or count(f:differential/f:element/f:type/f:code[@value and not(matches(string(@value), '^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$'))]|f:snapshot/f:element/f:type/f:code[@value and not(matches(string(@value), '^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$'))]) =0

constraint.requirements: element ids need to be unique
constraint.human: All element definitions must have unique ids (snapshot)
Context Invariants can only be used for extensions

constraint.requirements: element ids need to be unique
constraint.human: All element definitions must have unique ids (diff)

constraint.requirements: Ensure that element.base appears with base or not
constraint.human: element.base cannot appear if there is no base on the structure definition

constraint.requirements: Ensure that the type is not inconsistent with the other information in the structure
constraint.human: If there's a type, its content must match the path name in the first element of a snapshot
All element definitions must have an id
Element paths must be unique unless the structure is a constraint
If the structure describes a base Resource or Type, the URL has to start with "http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/" and the tail must match the id
A structure must have either a differential, or a snapshot (or both)
If the structure defines an extension then the structure must have context information
constraint.expression: type != 'Extension' or derivation = 'specialization' or (context.exists() and contextType.exists())

constraint.requirements: Ensure that the base types are abstract
constraint.human: If the structure is not abstract, then there SHALL be a baseDefinition

element.short: Logical URI to reference this structure definition (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this structure definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this structure definition is (or will be) published. The URL SHOULD include the major version of the structure definition. For more information see [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
element.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid:, but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same url if they have a distinct version.
element.requirements: Allows the structure definition to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the structure definition
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this structure definition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, e.g., to identify this structure definition outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the structure definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the structure definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the structure definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different structure definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a refrence to a particular business version of the structure definition with the format [url]|[version].

element.short: Name for this structure definition (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the structure definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alpha-numeric type name to ensure that it is computable friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this structure definition (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the structure definition.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc. Applications don't have to use this name, but can always fall back to it. The title also corresponds to the label for the root element.

element.definition: The status of this structure definition. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of structure definitions that are appropriate for use vs. not.  
This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired structure definition without due consideration.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of a Value Set or Concept Map.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A boolean value to indicate that this structure definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of structure definition that are appropriate for use vs. not. This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use an experimental structure definition in production.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level structure definition.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the structure definition was published. The date must change if and when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the structure definition changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the structure definition. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the structure definition.
element.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the structure definition is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the structure definition. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the structure definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the structure definition.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.short: Natural language description of the structure definition
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the structure definition from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the structure definition was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the structure definition as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the profile is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the profile was created).

element.short: Context the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate structure definition instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation whether all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for structure definition (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the structure definition is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the structure definition to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use

element.short: Why this structure definition is defined
element.definition: Explaination of why this structure definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the structure definition Instead  it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this structure definition.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the structure definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the structure definition.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the structure definition and/or its content.

element.definition: A set of key words or terms from external terminologies that may be used to assist with indexing and searching of templates.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate StructureDefinitions.

binding.description: Codes for the meaning of the defined structure (SNOMED CT and LOINC codes, as an example).

element.definition: The version of the FHIR specification on which this StructureDefinition is based - this is the formal version of the specification, without the revision number, e.g. [publication].[major].[minor], which is 3.0.1 for this version.
element.comment: A StructureDefinition does not need to specify the target it applies to,as StructureDefinitions will often be valid across multiple versions of FHIR. FHIR tooling can determine whether a StructureDefinition is consistent with a particular StructureDefinition if desired.

element.short: External specification that the content is mapped to
element.definition: An external specification that the content is mapped to.

constraint.human: Must have at least a name or a uri (or both)

element.short: Internal id when this mapping is used
element.definition: An Internal id that is used to identify this mapping set when specific mappings are made.
element.comment: The specification is described once, with general comments, and then specific mappings are made that reference this declaration.

element.short: Identifies what this mapping refers to
element.definition: An absolute URI that identifies the specification that this mapping is expressed to.
element.comment: A formal identity for the specification being mapped to helps with identifying maps consistently.

element.short: Names what this mapping refers to
element.definition: A name for the specification that is being mapped to.
Comments about this mapping, including version notes, issues, scope limitations, and other important notes for usage.
Defines the kind of structure that this definition is describing.

binding.description: Defines the type of structure that a definition is describing.

element.definition: Whether structure this definition describes is abstract or not  - that is, whether the structure is not intended to be instantiated. For Resources and Data types, abstract types will never be exchanged  between systems.
element.comment: Abstract Resources cannot be instantiated - a concrete sub-type must be used. Abstract datatypes and extensions cannot be used in an instance. For logical models, the exact implication of "abstract" will rest with the author, depending how the logical model is used. Flagging a constraint structure as abstract conveys design intent but makes no difference to how the structure definition is handled. Note that inline declared elements that are given the type "Element" in the profile, but have children described, are anonymous concrete types that specialise Element.

element.definition: If this is an extension, Identifies the context within FHIR resources where the extension can be used.

binding.description: How an extension context is interpreted.

element.short: Where the extension can be used in instances
element.definition: Identifies the types of resource or data type elements to which the extension can be applied.
element.comment: If the context is an element that can have multiple types, then use (e.g.) value[x] if the extension works on all choice types, or otherwise an enumeration of explicitly named elements if not. Note that a context of "string" doesn't mean that the extension can be used with one of the string patterns such as "id" etc.

element.short: FHIRPath invariants - when the extension can be used
element.definition: A set of rules as Fluent Invariants about when the extension can be used (e.g. co-occurrence variants for the extension).
element.comment: All the rules must be true. When evaluating the invariant, the fluentpath focus is the element that holds the extension, and %extension refers to the extension itself.

element.short: Type defined or constrained by this structure
element.definition: The type this structure describes. If the derivation kind is 'specialization' then this is the master definition for a type, and there is always one of these (a data type, an extension, a resource, including abstract ones). Otherwise the structure definition is a constraint on the stated type (and in this case, the type cannot be an abstract type).
element.comment: Note that in the case of constraints, the type could be determined by chasing through the baseDefinition references until a concrete structure (derivation = specialization) is reached, or by looking at the path of the first element in the snapshot - if present - but providing the type directly makes for simpler tooling and indexing.

binding.description: Either a resource or a data type, including logical model types

element.short: Definition that this type is constrained/specialized from
element.definition: An absolute URI that is the base structure from which this type is derived, either by specialization or constraint.
element.comment: If differential constraints are specified in this structure, they are applied to the base in a "differential" fashion. If there is no base, then the differential constraints cannot be provided (snapshot only). Differential structures are useful for the editing perspective, and snapshot structures are suitable for operational use. The FHIR Project provides a number of tools/services to populate snapshots from differential constraints. Logical Models have a base of "Element" or another logical model.

element.short: specialization | constraint - How relates to base definition
element.definition: How the type relates to the baseDefinition.
element.comment:
If the definition is a specialization, then it adds new elements in the differential, and the snapshot includes the inherited elements.

If the definition is a constraint, then it can not define new elements, it can only make new rules about existing content (see [Profiling Resources](profiling.html#resources)).

binding.description: How a type relates to its baseDefinition.

element.definition: A snapshot view is expressed in a stand alone form that can be used and interpreted without considering the base StructureDefinition.

In any snapshot, all the elements must be in the specified type
Each element definition in a snapshot must have a formal definition and cardinalities

element.definition: Captures constraints on each element within the resource.

The subscription resource is used to define a push based subscription from a server to another system. Once a subscription is registered with the server, the server checks every resource that is created or updated, and if the resource matches the given criteria, it sends a message on the defined "channel" so that another system is able to take an appropriate action.
The status of the subscription, which marks the server state for managing the subscription.
element.comment:
A client can only submit subscription resources in the requested or off state. Only the server can  move a subscription from requested to active, and then to error. Either the server or the client can turn a subscription off.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: The status of a subscription.

element.definition: Contact details for a human to contact about the subscription. The primary use of this for system administrator troubleshooting.

element.short: When to automatically delete the subscription
element.definition: The time for the server to turn the subscription off.
element.comment: The server is permitted to deviate from this time, but should observe it.

element.short: Description of why this subscription was created
element.definition: A description of why this subscription is defined.
The rules that the server should use to determine when to generate notifications for this subscription.
element.comment: The rules are a search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

element.definition: A record of the last error that occurred when the server processed a notification.

element.short: The channel on which to report matches to the criteria
element.definition: Details where to send notifications when resources are received that meet the criteria.
The type of channel to send notifications on.

binding.description: The type of method used to execute a subscription.

element.definition: The uri that describes the actual end-point to send messages to.
element.comment: For rest-hook, and websocket, the end-point must be an http: or https: URL; for email, a mailto: url, for sms, a tel: url, and for message the endpoint can be in any form of url the server understands (usually, http: or mllp:). The URI is allowed to be relative; in which case, it is relative to the server end-point (since their may be more than one, clients should avoid using relative URIs).

element.short: Mimetype to send, or omit for no payload
element.definition: The mime type to send the payload in - either application/fhir+xml, or application/fhir+json. If the payload is not present, then there is no payload in the notification, just a notification.
element.comment: Sending the payload has obvious security implications. The server is responsible for ensuring that the content is appropriately secured.

element.short: Usage depends on the channel type
element.definition: Additional headers / information to send as part of the notification.
element.comment: Exactly what these mean depend on the channel type. They can convey additional information to the recipient and/or meet security requirements; for example, support of multiple headers in the outgoing notifications for rest-hook type subscriptions.

element.short: A tag to add to matching resources
element.definition: A tag to add to any resource that matches the criteria, after the subscription is processed.
element.comment: So that other systems can tell which resources have been the subject of a notification.

binding.description: Tags to put on a resource after subscriptions have been sent.

resource.name: Substance
resource.publisher: Health Level Seven International (Orders and Observations)

element.short: A homogeneous material with a definite composition
element.definition: A homogeneous material with a definite composition.

mapping.map: fhir:Substance rdfs:subClassOf   rim:Entity, [      a owl:Restriction;     owl:onProperty  rim:Act.classCode;     owl:allValuesFrom  cs:EntityClass\#MAT   ].

element.definition: Unique identifier for the substance.
element.comment: This identifier is associated with the kind of substance in contrast to the  Substance.instance.identifier which is associated with the package/container.

element.definition: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used.

binding.description: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used

element.short: What class/type of substance this is
element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of substance.  This is used  for searching, sorting and display purposes.
element.comment: The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.   More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in Substance.code.

binding.description: Category or classification of substance

element.definition: A code (or set of codes) that identify this substance.
element.comment: This could be a reference to an externally defined code.  It could also be a locally assigned code (e.g. a formulary),  optionally with translations to the standard drug codes.

binding.description: Substance codes

element.short: Textual description of the substance, comments
element.definition: A description of the substance - its appearance, handling requirements, and other usage notes.

element.short: If this describes a specific package/container of the substance
element.definition: Substance may be used to describe a kind of substance, or a specific package/container of the substance: an instance.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If this element is not present, then the substance resource describes a kind of substance

element.definition: Identifier associated with the package/container (usually a label affixed directly).

element.short: When no longer valid to use
element.definition: When the substance is no longer valid to use. For some substances, a single arbitrary date is used for expiry.

element.short: Amount of substance in the package
element.definition: The amount of the substance.
A substance can be composed of other substances.
The amount of the ingredient in the substance - a concentration ratio.
Another substance that is a component of this substance.

binding.description: Substance Ingredient codes

resource.name: Task
resource.publisher: Health Level Seven International (Orders and Observations)

element.definition: A task to be performed.

constraint.human: Last modified date must be greater than or equal to authored-on date.
constraint.expression: lastModified.exists().not() or authoredOn.exists().not() or lastModified >= authoredOn
constraint.xpath: not(exists(f:lastModified/@value)) or not(exists(f:authoredOn/@value)) or f:lastModified/@value >= f:authoredOn/@value

element.definition: The business identifier for this task.
A reference to a formal or informal definition of the task.  For example, a protocol, a step within a defined workflow definition, etc.
element.requirements: Enables a formal definition of how he task is to be performed (e.g. using BPMN, BPEL, XPDL or other formal notation) to be associated with a task, enabling automation.

element.definition: BasedOn refers to a higher-level authorization that triggered the creation of the task.  It references a "request" resource such as a ProcedureRequest, MedicationRequest, ProcedureRequest, CarePlan, etc. which is distinct from the "request" resource the task is seeking to fulfil.  This latter resource is referenced by FocusOn.  For example, based on a ProcedureRequest (= BasedOn), a task is created to fulfil a procedureRequest ( = FocusOn ) to collect a specimen from a patient.
An identifier that links together multiple tasks and other requests that were created in the same context.
element.requirements: Billing and/or reporting can be linked to whether multiple requests were created as a single unit.

element.definition: Task that this particular task is part of.
element.comment: This should usually be 0..1.
element.requirements: Allows tasks to be broken down into sub-steps (and this division can occur independent of the original task).

element.definition: The current status of the task.
element.requirements: These states enable coordination of task status with off-the-shelf workflow solutions that support automation of tasks.

binding.description: The current status of the task.

element.definition: An explanation as to why this task is held, failed, was refused, etc.
element.comment: This applies to the current status.  Look at the history of the task to see reasons for past statuses.

binding.description: Codes to identify the reason for current status.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

element.definition: Contains business-specific nuances of the business state.
element.requirements: There's often a need to track substates of a task - this is often variable by specific workflow implementation.

binding.description: The domain-specific business-contextual sub-state of the task.  For example: "Blood drawn", "IV inserted", "Awaiting physician signature", etc.

element.definition: Indicates the "level" of actionability associated with the Task.  I.e. Is this a proposed task, a planned task, an actionable task, etc.
element.comment:
This element is immutable.  Proposed tasks, planned tasks, etc. must be distinct instances.

In most cases, Tasks will have an intent of "order".

binding.description: Distinguishes whether the task is a proposal, plan or full order

element.definition: Indicates how quickly the Task should be addressed with respect to other requests.
element.requirements: Used to identify the service level expected while performing a task.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If missing, this task should be performed with normal priority

binding.description: The task's priority

element.definition: A name or code (or both) briefly describing what the task involves.
element.comment: The title (eg "My Tasks", "Outstanding Tasks for Patient X") should go into the code.

binding.description: Codes to identify what the task involves.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

element.definition: A free-text description of what is to be performed.
The request being actioned or the resource being manipulated by this task.
element.comment: If multiple resources need to be manipulated, use sub-tasks.  (This ensures that status can be tracked independently for each referenced resource.).
element.requirements: Used to identify the thing to be done.

element.definition: The entity who benefits from the performance of the service specified in the task (e.g., the patient).
element.requirements: Used to track tasks outstanding for a beneficiary.  Do not use to track the task owner or creator (see owner and creator respectively).  This can also affect access control.

element.short: Healthcare event during which this task originated
element.definition: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this task was created.
element.requirements: For some tasks it may be important to know the link between the task or episode of care the task originated within.

element.short: Start and end time of execution
element.definition: Identifies the time action was first taken against the task (start) and/or the time final action was taken against the task prior to marking it as completed (end).
The date and time this task was created.
element.requirements: Most often used along with lastUpdated to track duration of task to supporting monitoring and management.

element.definition: The date and time of last modification to this task.
element.requirements: Used along with history to track task activity and time in a particular task state.  This enables monitoring and management.

element.short: Who is asking for task to be done
element.definition: The creator of the task.
element.requirements: Identifies who created this task.  May be used by access control mechanisms (e.g., to ensure that only the creator can cancel a task).

element.definition: The device, practitioner, etc. who initiated the task.
The organization the device or practitioner was acting on behalf of when they initiated the task.
element.requirements: Practitioners and Devices can be associated with multiple organizations.  This element indicates which organization they were acting on behalf of when authoring the request.

element.short: requester | dispatcher | scheduler | performer | monitor | manager | acquirer | reviewer
element.definition: The type of participant that can execute the task.
element.requirements: Use to distinguish tasks on different activity queues.

binding.description: The type(s) of task performers allowed

element.definition: Individual organization or Device currently responsible for task execution.
element.comment: Tasks may be created with an owner not yet identified.
element.requirements: Identifies who is expected to perform this task.

element.definition: A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
element.comment: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.

binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed.  E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

element.definition: Free-text information captured about the task as it progresses.

element.short: Key events in history of the Task
element.definition: Links to Provenance records for past versions of this Task that identify key state transitions or updates that are likely to be relevant to a user looking at the current version of the task.
element.comment: This element does not point to the Provenance associated with the *current* version of the resource - as it would be created after this version existed.  The Provenance for the current version can be retrieved with a _revinclude.

element.definition: If the Task.focus is a request resource and the task is seeking fulfillment (i.e is asking for the request to be actioned), this element identifies any limitations on what parts of the referenced request should be actioned.
element.requirements: Sometimes when fulfillment is sought, you don't want full fulfillment.

mapping.map: Instead of pointing to request, would point to component of request, having these characteristics

element.definition: Indicates the number of times the requested action should occur.
element.requirements: E.g. order that requests monthly lab tests, fulfillment is sought for 1.

element.definition: Over what time-period is fulfillment sought.
element.comment: Note that period.high is the due date representing the time by which the task should be completed.
element.requirements: E.g. order that authorizes 1 year's services.  Fulfillment is sought for next 3 months.

element.definition: For requests that are targeted to more than on potential recipient/target, for whom is fulfillment sought?
Additional information that may be needed in the execution of the task.
element.requirements: Resources and data used to perform the task.  This data is used in the business logic of task execution, and is stored separately because it varies between workflows.

element.definition: A code or description indicating how the input is intended to be used as part of the task execution.
element.comment: If referencing a BPMN workflow or Protocol, the "system" is the URL for the workflow definition and the code is the "name" of the required input.
element.requirements: Inputs are named to enable task automation to bind data and pass it from one task to the next.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Comparison source", "Applicable consent", "Concommitent Medications", etc.

element.short: Content to use in performing the task
element.definition: The value of the input parameter as a basic type.

element.short: Information produced as part of task
element.definition: Outputs produced by the Task.
element.requirements: Resources and data produced during the execution the task.  This data is generated by the business logic of task execution, and is stored separately because it varies between workflows.

element.definition: The name of the Output parameter.
element.requirements: Outputs are named to enable task automation to bind data and pass it from one task to the next.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Identified issues", "Preliminary results", "Filler order", "Final results", etc.

element.definition: The value of the Output parameter as a basic type.
element.requirements: Task outputs can take any form.

element.short: Describes the results of a TestScript execution
element.definition: A summary of information based on the results of executing a TestScript.
Identifier for the TestScript assigned for external purposes outside the context of FHIR.

element.short: Informal name of the executed TestScript
element.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the executed TestScript.
element.comment: Not expected to be globally unique.

element.definition: The current state of this test report.
element.comment:
The status represents where the execution is currently within the test script execution life cycle.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: The current status of the test report.

element.short: Reference to the  version-specific TestScript that was executed to produce this TestReport
element.definition: Ideally this is an absolute URL that is used to identify the version-specific TestScript that was executed, matching the `TestScript.url`.
The overall result from the execution of the TestScript.
element.comment: The pass and fail result represents a completed test script execution. The pending result represents a test script execution that has not yet started or is currently in progress.

binding.description: The reported execution result.

element.short: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript
element.definition: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript.

element.short: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual)
element.definition: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual).
element.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the TestReport.  May also allow for contact.

element.short: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated
element.definition: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated.
element.comment: Additional specific dates may be added as extensions.

element.short: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server
element.definition: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server.
The type of participant.

binding.description: The type of participant.

element.short: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred
element.definition: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred.

element.short: The display name of the participant
element.definition: The display name of the participant.

element.short: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed
element.definition: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed.

element.short: A setup operation or assert that was executed
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.human: Setup action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.
constraint.xpath: (f:operation or f:assert) and not(f:operation and f:assert)

element.definition: The operation performed.
The result of this operation.

binding.description: The results of executing an action.

element.short: A message associated with the result
element.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

element.short: A link to further details on the result
element.definition: A link to further details on the result.
The results of the assertion performed on the previous operations.
The result of this assertion.

binding.description: The results of executing an action.

element.short: A message associated with the result
element.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

element.short: A link to further details on the result
element.definition: A link to further details on the result.

element.short: A test executed from the test script
element.definition: A test executed from the test script.
The name of this test used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

element.short: Tracking/reporting short description of the test
element.definition: A short description of the test used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

element.short: A test operation or assert that was performed
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.human: Test action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.
constraint.xpath: (f:operation or f:assert) and not(f:operation and f:assert)

element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.
The results of the assertion performed on the previous operations.

element.short: The results of running the series of required clean up steps
element.definition: The results of the series of operations required to clean up after the all the tests were executed (successfully or otherwise).

element.short: One or more teardown operations performed
element.definition: The teardown action will only contain an operation.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.
A structured set of tests against a FHIR server implementation to determine compliance against the FHIR specification.

element.short: Logical URI to reference this test script (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. This SHALL be a URL, SHOULD be globally unique, and SHOULD be an address at which this test script is (or will be) published. The URL SHOULD include the major version of the test script. For more information see [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
element.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid:, but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same url if they have a distinct version.
element.requirements: Allows the test script to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the test script
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this test script when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, e.g., to identify this test script outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the test script
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the test script author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different test script instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a refrence to a particular business version of the test script with the format [url]|[version].

element.short: Name for this test script (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the test script. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alpha-numeric type name to ensure that it is computable friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this test script (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the test script.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.definition: The status of this test script. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of test scripts that are appropriate for use vs. not.  
This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired test script without due consideration.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of a Value Set or Concept Map.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A boolean value to indicate that this test script is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of test script that are appropriate for use vs. not. This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use an experimental test script in production.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level test script.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the test script was published. The date must change if and when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the test script changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the test script. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the test script.
element.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the test script is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the test script. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the test script. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the test script.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.short: Natural language description of the test script
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the test script from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the test script was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the test script as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the profile is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the profile was created).

element.short: Context the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate test script instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation whether all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for test script (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the test script is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the test script to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use

element.short: Why this test script is defined
element.definition: Explaination of why this test script is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the test script Instead  it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this test script.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the test script and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the test script.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the test script and/or its content.

element.short: An abstract server representing a client or sender in a message exchange
element.definition: An abstract server used in operations within this test script in the origin element.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to define the profile of an origin element used elsewhere in the script.  Test engines could then use the origin-profile mapping to offer a filtered list of test systems that can serve as the sender for the interaction.

element.short: The index of the abstract origin server starting at 1
element.definition: Abstract name given to an origin server in this test script.  The name is provided as a number starting at 1.
element.comment:
A given origin index (e.g. 1) can appear only once in the list (e.g. Origin 1 cannot be specified twice ... once as FormFiller and and again as FormProcessor within the same script as that could get confusing during test configuration). 

Different origin indices could play the same actor in the same test script (e.g. You could have two different test systems acting as Form-Filler).

The origin indices provided elsewhere in the test script must be one of these origin indices.

element.definition: The type of origin profile the test system supports.
element.comment: Must be a "sender"/"client" profile.
element.meaningWhenMissing: FHIR-Client

binding.description: The type of origin profile the test system supports.

element.short: An abstract server representing a destination or receiver in a message exchange
element.definition: An abstract server used in operations within this test script in the destination element.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to define the profile of a destination element used elsewhere in the script.  Test engines could then use the destination-profile mapping to offer a filtered list of test systems that can serve as the receiver for the interaction.

element.short: The index of the abstract destination server starting at 1
element.definition: Abstract name given to a destination server in this test script.  The name is provided as a number starting at 1.
element.comment:
A given destination index (e.g. 1) can appear only once in the list (e.g. Destination 1 cannot be specified twice ... once as Form-Manager and again as Form-Processor within the same script as that could get confusing during test configuration). 

Different destination indices could play the same actor in the same test script (e.g. You could have two different test systems acting as Form-Manager).

The destination indices provided elsewhere in the test script must be one of these destination indices.

element.definition: The type of destination profile the test system supports.
element.comment: Must be a "receiver"/"server" profile.
element.meaningWhenMissing: FHIR-Server

binding.description: The type of destination profile the test system supports.

element.short: Required capability that is assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested
element.definition: The required capability must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.

constraint.human: TestScript metadata capability SHALL contain required or validated or both.
constraint.xpath: f:capability/f:required or f:capability/f:validated or (f:capability/f:required and f:capability/f:validated)

element.definition: A link to the FHIR specification that this test is covering.
URL to a particular requirement or feature within the FHIR specification.
Short description of the link.

element.short: Capabilities  that are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested
element.definition: Capabilities that must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.
element.comment: When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.metadata or at TestScript.setup.metadata, and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then all the tests in the TestScript are skipped.  When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.test.metadata and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then only that test is skipped.  The "metadata.capabilities.required" and "metadata.capabilities.validated" elements only indicate whether the capabilities are the primary focus of the test script or not.  They do not impact the skipping logic.  Capabilities whose "metadata.capabilities.validated" flag is true are the primary focus of the test script.

element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will require the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.
Whether or not the test execution will validate the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.

element.short: The expected capabilities of the server
element.definition: Description of the capabilities that this test script is requiring the server to support.

element.short: Which origin server these requirements apply to
element.definition: Which origin server these requirements apply to.

element.short: Which server these requirements apply to
element.definition: Which server these requirements apply to.
Links to the FHIR specification that describes this interaction and the resources involved in more detail.
Minimum capabilities required of server for test script to execute successfully.   If server does not meet at a minimum the referenced capability statement, then all tests in this script are skipped.
element.comment: The conformance statement of the server has to contain at a minimum the contents of the reference pointed to by this element.

element.short: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri)
element.definition: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri). All fixtures are required for the test script to execute.

element.short: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup. If true, the fixture is automatically created on each server being tested during setup, therefore no create operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.setup section.

element.short: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown. If true, the fixture is automatically deleted on each server being tested during teardown, therefore no delete operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.teardown section.
Reference to the resource (containing the contents of the resource needed for operations).
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.

element.definition: Reference to the profile to be used for validation.
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.

element.definition: Variable is set based either on element value in response body or on header field value in the response headers.
element.comment: Variables would be set based either on XPath/JSONPath expressions against fixtures (static and response), or headerField evaluations against response headers. If variable evaluates to nodelist or anything other than a primitive value, then test engine would report an error.  Variables would be used to perform clean replacements in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations. This limits the places that test engines would need to look for placeholders "${}".  Variables are scoped to the whole script. They are NOT evaluated at declaration. They are evaluated by test engine when used for substitutions in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations.  See example testscript-search.xml.

constraint.human: Variable can only contain one of expression, headerField or path.

element.definition: Descriptive name for this variable.
element.comment: Placeholders would contain the variable name wrapped in ${} in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" elements.  These placeholders would need to be replaced by the variable value before the operation is executed.

element.short: Default, hard-coded, or user-defined value for this variable
element.definition: A default, hard-coded, or user-defined value for this variable.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to allow for a pre-defined value that can be used as a default or as an override value. Test engines can optionally use this as a placeholder for user-defined execution time values.

element.short: Natural language description of the variable
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the variable and its purpose.

element.short: The fluentpath expression against the fixture body
element.definition: The fluentpath expression to evaluate against the fixture body. When variables are defined, only one of either expression, headerField or path must be specified.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to.  If expression or path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to.  It is an error to define any combination of expression, headerField and path.

element.short: HTTP header field name for source
element.definition: Will be used to grab the HTTP header field value from the headers that sourceId is pointing to.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to.  If path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to.  It is an error to define both headerField and path.

element.short: Hint help text for default value to enter
element.definition: Displayable text string with hint help information to the user when entering a default value.

element.short: XPath or JSONPath against the fixture body
element.definition: XPath or JSONPath to evaluate against the fixture body.  When variables are defined, only one of either expression, headerField or path must be specified.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to.  If expression or path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to.  It is an error to define any combination of expression, headerField and path.

element.short: Fixture Id of source expression or headerField within this variable
element.definition: Fixture to evaluate the XPath/JSONPath expression or the headerField  against within this variable.
element.comment: This can be a statically defined fixture (at the top of the TestScript) or a dynamically set fixture created by responseId of the `action.operation` element.

element.short: Assert rule used within the test script
element.definition: Assert rule to be used in one or more asserts within the test script.
element.comment: Each rule should be treated by test engines as one assertion regardless of how many assertions are contained within the external rule template.  The impact of negative rule evaluation on test script execution is the same as an assertion failure which is described elsewhere in the TestScript resource.

element.definition: Reference to the resource (containing the contents of the rule needed for assertions).
Each rule template can take one or more parameters for rule evaluation.
element.comment: The parameter value can be dynamic at runtime.

element.short: Parameter name matching external assert rule parameter
element.definition: Descriptive name for this parameter that matches the external assert rule parameter name.
element.comment: The external rule template would be looking for the parameter by this name.

element.short: Parameter value defined either explicitly or dynamically
element.definition: The explicit or dynamic value for the parameter that will be passed on to the external rule template.
element.comment: This value can be overwritten by the assert.rule.param.value i.e. TestScript.rule.param.value will be used if assert.rule.param.value is not specified.  The param value can be a string-representation of a number, string, or boolean that is expected. Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before supplying this value to the external rule template.

element.short: Assert ruleset used within the test script
element.definition: Contains one or more rules.  Offers a way to group rules so assertions could reference the group of rules and have them all applied.
element.comment: Each rule within a ruleset should be treated by test engines as one assertion regardless of how many assertions are contained within the external rule template.  The impact of negative rule evaluation on test script execution is the same as an assertion failure which is described elsewhere in the TestScript resource.

element.definition: Reference to the resource (containing the contents of the ruleset needed for assertions).

element.short: The referenced rule within the ruleset
element.definition: The referenced rule within the external ruleset template.
element.comment: This qualifies each param name so that  a parameter with the same name can be used differently by the different rules with the ruleset.

element.short: Id of referenced rule within the ruleset
element.definition: Id of the referenced rule within the external ruleset template.
Each rule template can take one or more parameters for rule evaluation.
element.comment: The parameter value can be dynamic at runtime.

element.short: Parameter name matching external assert ruleset rule parameter
element.definition: Descriptive name for this parameter that matches the external assert ruleset rule parameter name.
element.comment: The external rule template would be looking for the parameter by this name.

element.short: Parameter value defined either explicitly or dynamically
element.definition: The value for the parameter that will be passed on to the external ruleset rule template.
element.comment: This value can be overwritten by the assert.ruleset.rule.param.value i.e. TestScript.ruleset.rule.param.value will be used if assert.ruleset.rule.param.value is not specified.  The param value can be a string-representation of a number, string, or boolean that is expected. Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before supplying this value to the external rule template.

element.short: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed
element.definition: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed.

element.short: A setup operation or assert to perform
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.human: Setup action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.
constraint.xpath: (f:operation or f:assert) and not(f:operation and f:assert)

element.definition: The operation to perform.

constraint.human: Setup operation SHALL contain either sourceId or targetId or params or url.
constraint.expression: sourceId.exists() or (targetId.count() + url.count() + params.count() = 1) or (type.code in ('capabilities' |'search' | 'transaction' | 'history'))
constraint.xpath: f:sourceId or ((f:targetId or f:url or f:params) and (count(f:targetId) + count(f:url) + count(f:params) =1)) or (f:type/f:code/@value='capabilities' or f:type/f:code/@value='search' or f:type/f:code/@value='transaction' or f:type/f:code/@value='history')

element.short: The operation code type that will be executed
element.definition: Server interaction or operation type.
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/http.html for list of server interactions.

binding.description: The allowable operation code types.

element.definition: The type of the resource.  See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.

binding.description: Either a resource or a data type.

element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.definition: The description would be used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.definition: The content-type or mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Accept' header.
element.comment: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Accept' header to the corresponding value.    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Accept' header of 'application/fhir+xml' will be set.  If 'json' is specified, then 'application/fhir+json' will be used.    If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Accept' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.
element.meaningWhenMissing: xml

binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.definition: The content-type or mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Content-Type' header.
element.comment: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Content-Type' header to the corresponding value.    If 'xml' is specified, then 'Content-Type' header of 'application/fhir+xml' will be set.    If 'json' is specified, then 'application/fhir+json' will be used.    If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Content-Type' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.
element.meaningWhenMissing: xml

binding.description: The content or mime type.

element.definition: The server where the request message is destined for.  Must be one of the server numbers listed in TestScript.destination section.
element.comment: If multiple TestScript.destination elements are defined and operation.destination is undefined, test engine will report an error as it cannot determine what destination to use for the exchange.

element.short: Whether or not to send the request url in encoded format
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly send the request url in encoded format. The default is true to match the standard RESTful client behavior. Set to false when communicating with a server that does not support encoded url paths.
The server where the request message originates from.  Must be one of the server numbers listed in TestScript.origin section.
element.comment: If absent, test engine will send the message.  When present, test engine will not send the request message but will wait for the request message to be sent from this origin server.

element.definition: Path plus parameters after [type].  Used to set parts of the request URL explicitly.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.   Test engines would append whatever is specified for "params" to the URL after the resource type without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP).  The "params" element does not correspond exactly to "search parameters".  Nor is it the "path".  It corresponds to the part of the URL that comes after the [type] (when "resource" element is specified); e.g. It corresponds to "/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}" in the following operation: GET [base]/[type]/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.short: Each operation can have one or more header elements
element.definition: Header elements would be used to set HTTP headers.
element.comment: This gives control to test-script writers to set headers explicitly based on test requirements.  It will allow for testing using:  - "If-Modified-Since" and "If-None-Match" headers.  See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.5.1 - "If-Match" header.  See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.11 - Conditional Create using "If-None-Exist".  See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.13.1 - Invalid "Content-Type" header for negative testing. - etc.

element.definition: The HTTP header field e.g. "Accept".
element.comment: If header element is specified, then field is required.

element.definition: The value of the header e.g. "application/fhir+xml".
element.comment: If header element is specified, then value is required.  No conversions will be done by the test engine e.g. "xml" to "application/fhir+xml".  The values will be set in HTTP headers "as-is".  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the request.
element.comment: If a requestId is supplied, then the resulting request (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "requestId".  If requestId is not specified, it is the test engine's responsibility to store the request and use it as the requestId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified, direction is equal to request, and the requestId in not specified.

element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the response.
element.comment: If a responseId is supplied, and the server responds, then the resulting response (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "responseId".  If responseId is not specified, it is the test engine's responsibility to store the response and use it as the responseId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified and the responseId is not specified.

element.short: Fixture Id of body for PUT and POST requests
element.definition: The id of the fixture used as the body of a PUT or POST request.

element.short: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id],  [type], and [vid] for GET requests
element.definition: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id],  [type], and [vid] for GET requests.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url.  If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored.  For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified.  If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present.  For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url.  For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.

element.definition: Complete request URL.
element.comment: Used to set the request URL explicitly.  If "url" element is defined, then "targetId", "resource", and "params" elements will be ignored.  Test engines would use whatever is specified in "url" without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP).  Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.definition: Evaluates the results of previous operations to determine if the server under test behaves appropriately.
element.comment: In order to evaluate an assertion, the request, response, and results of the most recently executed operation must always be maintained by the test engine.

constraint.human: Only a single assertion SHALL be present within setup action assert element.
constraint.expression: contentType.count() + expression.count() + headerField.count() + minimumId.count() + navigationLinks.count() + path.count() + requestMethod.count() + resource.count() + responseCode.count() + response.count() + rule.count() + ruleset.count() + validateProfileId.count() <=1
constraint.xpath: count(f:contentType) + count(f:expression) + count(f:headerField) + count(f:minimumId) + count(f:navigationLinks) + count(f:path) + count(f:requestMethod) + count(f:resource) + count(f:responseCode) + count(f:response) + count(f:rule) + count(f:ruleset) + count(f:validateProfileId)  <=1

constraint.human: Setup action assert SHALL contain either compareToSourceId and compareToSourceExpression, compareToSourceId and compareToSourcePath or neither.
constraint.xpath: (f:compareToSourceId and f:compareToSourceExpression) or (f:compareToSourceId and f:compareToSourcePath) or not(f:compareToSourceId or f:compareToSourceExpression or f:compareToSourcePath)

constraint.human: Setup action assert response and responseCode SHALL be empty when direction equals request
constraint.expression: (response.empty() and responseCode.empty() and direction = 'request') or direction.empty() or direction = 'response'

element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.
